centralQuestion: Were Trump's initial 2018 tariffs beneficial in hindsight?

reasons.description: Strengthened U.S. steel and aluminum industries via Section 232 actions, with reported increases in output, investment, and capacity utilization.

sources.title: Economic Policy Institute: 'Aluminum tariffs have led to a strong recovery in employment, production, and investment in primary aluminum and downstream industries'
Economic Policy Institute: 'Why Global Steel Surpluses Warrant U.S. Section 232 Import Measures'

reasons.description: Created negotiating leverage that contributed to trade agreements and concessions (e.g., USMCA, elements of the China 'Phase One' deal).

sources.title: Brookings Institution: 'What was Trump's trade policy legacy?'
Council on Foreign Relations: 'NAFTA and the USMCA: Weighing the Impact of North American Trade'

reasons.description: Encouraged diversification of supply chains away from China—toward allies and partners—reducing strategic dependence.

sources.title: Center for Strategic and International Studies: 'Diversifying Supply Chains: The Role of Development Assistance and Trade Policy'
Reuters: 'Trump administration pushing to rip global supply chains from China: officials'

reasons.description: Increased tariff revenue to the U.S. Treasury.

sources.title: Reuters: 'Who pays Trump's tariffs, China or U.S. customers and companies?'

objections.description: U.S. consumers and firms bore most of the tariff costs; prices rose for imported inputs and consumer goods.

sources.title: Peterson Institute for International Economics: 'Trump’s plan to expand tariffs would raise prices on essentials for U.S. households'
OECD: 'OECD Economic Outlook, Interim Report September 2019'

objections.description: Retaliation from trading partners harmed U.S. farmers and exporters, prompting large federal aid payments.

sources.title: Associated Press: 'US farmers who sell to China feel pain of Beijing’s tariffs'
Associated Press: 'Louisiana farmers get $180M in federal aid for tariff losses'

objections.description: Net welfare and GDP losses; trade tensions slowed global growth and investment.
The overall U.S. trade deficit did not shrink in a sustained way; effects were mainly compositional (shifts toward Mexico/Vietnam).

sources.title: Reuters: 'Trump upended trade once, aims to do so again with new tariffs'

objections.description: Administrative uncertainty and an ad hoc tariff exclusion process increased business costs and favored some firms over others.

sources.title: Peterson Institute for International Economics: 'USTR’s tariff exclusion process: Five things to know'

research.title: Quarterly Journal of Economics: 'The Return to Protectionism'
research.description: Quantifies U.S. 2018–2019 tariffs and retaliations, finding near-complete pass-through to domestic prices, sizable deadweight losses, and trade diversion with limited producer gains.

research.title: AER: Insights: 'Tariff Pass-Through at the Border and at the Store: Evidence from US Trade Policy'
research.description: Documents that 2018–2019 tariffs raised U.S. import prices at the border and retail prices in stores, implying U.S. consumers bore much of the burden.

research.title: Journal of Economic Perspectives: 'The Impact of the 2018 Tariffs on Prices and Welfare'
research.description: Shows importers largely paid the tariffs, with estimated welfare losses for the U.S.; synthesizes early evidence on price effects and incidence.
